alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for tool allowances
overview: If your business provides a tool allowance to employees - what you must report to HMRC
title: Expenses and benefits: tool allowances

table.body:
As an employer providing a tool allowance to your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

##What's included

A tool allowance is a payment you give to an employee to buy tools that are only used for work.


*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You don’t have to report anything to HMRC or pay tax and National Insurance if you provide a tool allowance for an employee earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year.

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If the tool allowances aren't [exempt](//expenses-and-benefits-tool-allowances/whats-exempt "exempt"), you may have to report them to HMRC and deduct tax and National Insurance on the costs.

^You can [apply for a dispensation](/apply-for-a-dispensation “apply for a dispensation) to cover tool allowances. This means you won’t have to include them in your end-of year reports.^

If you don't have a dispensation, for employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year, or directors, report on form P11D, section N.  

##If work tools are available for employees to use privately

The allowance you provide counts as earnings. Add the amount to the employee's other earnings, and deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll. 

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]:Pay as you earn
